Situation1: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story: The lunch rush at the grocery store was in full swing, and I moved quickly behind the register, scanning items and offering smiles to the endless line of customers. My manager expected me to keep things moving, to be friendly and efficient, and I could see the impatience in the faces of those waiting. I tried to focus on each person, making small talk, remembering that a kind word could brighten someone’s day. But as I handed a receipt to a customer, I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until the main weekly service at the church, the one I was supposed to lead. My congregation counted on me to be there, to guide them in prayer and offer comfort. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing on me, knowing how much they valued my presence. My heart pounded as I looked at the growing line, torn between my duty to these customers and my responsibility to my community of faith. The minutes ticked by, and I stood frozen, caught between two worlds, each demanding more than I felt I could give.
